title: Eliminating Waste and Saving Taxpayer Dollars by Consolidating Procurement

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs federal agencies to consolidate their purchasing of common goods and services under the General Services Administration to reduce waste, avoid duplication, and save taxpayer money. It also designates the Administrator of General Services as the lead for government-wide IT procurement contracts to promote efficiency and coordination across agencies.
potential_concerns: Consolidating procurement under the General Services Administration may reduce opportunities for small-business-owners and certain federal-contractors to compete for government contracts, potentially limiting market diversity and disadvantaging specialized vendors.
Centralizing IT procurement could create a bottleneck that delays agency-specific technology upgrades, negatively impacting federal contractors specializing in niche IT products or services.

While targeting government-efficiency and federal-spending reductions, the order could inadvertently reduce innovation and flexibility if GSA standardized contracts limit agencies' ability to tailor procurement to specific mission needs.

The reduced duplication intended to save taxpayer dollars might result in heavier reliance on large suppliers favored by consolidated contracts, increasing market concentration and potentially increasing costs or reducing supplier resilience.
